LETT
THE NEWS
VOL. XVI, NO. 7.
FINNEY AS PRINCETON'S HEAD
The Unanimous Choice of Sub-Committee of Trustees --He Will
Probably Accept.

The sub-committee of the board
of trustees of Princeton University
appointed to select a nominee for
the presidency of the university, it
has been learned from trustworthy
sources, has come to a unanimous
agreement upon Dr. John M. T.
Finney, Associate Professor of
Surgery in the Johns Hopkins University, for the place. In the event
f unanimity in the sub-committee
it has all along been understood
that the trustees would accept the
recommendation. It is also understood that Dr. Finney will make no
decision in the matter until the
Opinion of the entire board has been
expressed. The next regular meeting of the trustees will be held in
January. Thus far no notice of a
special meeting has been given.
.The class of 1884, of which Dr.
Finney is a member, has forwarded
to him a letter of congratulation,
urging him to accept the presidency.
Members of the class think that he
will accept.
'His intimate connection with the
management of the Hopkins Medical School and its educational questions has been an important factor
in considering him for the presidency. Another factor commending him has been the fact that in
his work on the board of trustees
of Princeton since his election in
the spring of 1910 has been his
Special effort on the committee for
the reorganization of the department of physical education. He
was a member of the Baltimore
School Board for a time and is a
trustee of the Gilman School of
Baltimore.
In college they call Finney "J'ai
nni," because it sounded like his
name and because he finished
things. He was an athlete, playing
end on a football team that beat
both Havard and Yale. He did not
class with the first ten in scholarship but was a good student.
Dr. Finney is 48 years old, a
native of Harford county, Md. He
is the son of Rev. Ebenezer Finney, a Presbyterian minister. He
was educated in the Maryland
county schools, then Princeton, with
his medical education at Harvard.
At the meeting of the Philological Association, held last Friday,
the papers presented were as follows: "The Greek Aorist Passive
and the Germanic Weak Preterit,"
by Prof. Collitz ; "The Judaization
of Idumea," by Prof. Paul Haupt.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 20, 1911.

HOPKINS CRUSHES
ST. JOHN'S, 1610 0
A Crowd of Over 5,000 Witness
Battle on Sea of Mud.
THE SOLDIER BOYS OUTCLASSED
Rooters Out in Force With Bands to
Cheer the Squads—Game Ended
With Usual Snake Dance.

Once more the historic event of
the Hopkins football season resulted
in a triumph for the wearers of the
Black and Blue, when St. John's
went down to defeat last Saturday
by the decisive score of 16 to o.
Contrary to the predictions of the
wise dopesters and the warnings of
the knockers, Lynn's men "came
back" and proved that the regular
team of the present season is worthy
of the whole-hearted support of
their backers. Filled with a grim
determination to wipe out the defeat of the week before by winning the contest on which more than
anything else were staked the hopes
of the enthusiasts, the players went
into the game with a rush and snap
that overcame their opponents' wily
trick plays, broke up their runs,
tore through their lines, and eventually disheartened their whole organization.
A tremendous crowd assembled
for the contest. The rooters of
both sides were out in force with
their bands, and never left off
cheering their favorites during the
whole game. Although St. John's
had been the choice of the wise
ones during the whole week before,
it was seen that the wet condition
of the grounds, which would compel the employment of the old-time
straight football to a large extent,
was against their tactics, and the
local boys were correspondingly
more jubilant.
The first few minutes of play
seemed to exhaust the resources of
the soldier boys. Their forward
passes and clever tricks made a distinct impression during the first
quarter, but as the ball became wet
and the runners lost some of their
speed in the mud, the visitors were
seen to be unequal to the Hopkins
team. In particular, their backs
were unable often to get away from
the fast ends, who broke through
or around the line and frequently
threw the runners for a loss. On
the other hand, the Hopkins backs
showed speed when least expected,
and the interference protected them
admirably in running back kicks.

Stollenwerck's presence in the backfield was a distinct help to the men,
and the team was always a unit
with a single mind in control. Conditions were unfavorable for kicking, and the veteran quarter's efforts at field goals went wide time
after time. It was soon evident
that the game would be won largely
on line bucking, and here Hopkins
,excelled.
In open field work, the tackling
of Musser and "Johnnie" Morton
was often sensational. They broke
up many plays that threatened long
gains for the visitors. Bridgman,
as ever, was a consistent ground
gainer and showed his old knowledge of the fine points of the game.
He and Gillet would alternately
tAke the ball forward, and both
seemed utterly tireless in their
splendid plunging and running.
Fulton was relieved of much of the
overwork that had been his fate
when the team was stripped of the
older players, but during the time
he played he showed his usual brilliant form.
Rhode and Gittings won the
cheers of the grandstand by numerous brilliant plays. The former
especially showed head work constantly and helped the younger men
by his thorough knowledge of the
game. Pieper was always reliable
and worked hard throughout. The
backfield quartet was the best seen
in the Hopkins uniform this year,
and in spite of the slippery condition of the ball, it was handled almost without a mishap.
Bridgman kicked off to Melville,
who was downed on the 25-yard
line. The visitors immediately
worked a forward pass for a long
gain, but were compelled soon after
to kick. Bridgman and Gillet carried the ball rapidly down the field,
but St. Johns held on the 15-yard
line, secured the ball, and punted
out. A fumble lost the ball again,
but St. John's could not gain, and
Clayton kicked to Stollenwerck.
After some gains, Bridgman punted
back, and this time clever work and
good luck brought the visitors to
the Hopkins bo-yard line. Here St.
John's tried the forward pass that
had stood, them in such good stead
before. This time Claude fumbled,
and Hopkins secured the ball. After
sonic unsuccessful,tries through the
line, the bail was punted back again,
and at the close of the quarter was
in the possession of the visitors on
the 13-yard line.
When play was resumed, the
Black and Blue held for downs;
Bridgman and Stollenwerck made
brilliant gains. From this point St.
John's was always on the defensive.
Several kicks were exchanged arid

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TO BUILD IN THE SPRING
A Committee of Trustees, Faculty and
Alumni to Be Appointed to Supervise Work at Homewood.

Important announcements have
been made by President Remsen
in regard to the beginning of building operations at Homewood. A
committee of the trustees, faculty,
and alumni to take active charge
of the supervision of the work
is being made up and its personnel will be announced in a few
days. The committee will be modeled on the lines of the Endowment
and Extension Fund Committee of
1910, and will hold frequent meetings.
The preliminary plans are complete, and the work of finally deciding upon these, and awarding the
contracts, will be done this winter,
so that the construction can be
started in the spring, as soon as
the weather permits. Studies of
the Academic and Library Building-, the Administration, or Gilman,
Building, three laboratories and a
Y. M. C. A. building have been
made, and it will be the work of
the Committee to pass on these
plans, secure bids and make recommendations to the trustees for final
action. The question of steam-heat,
light and drainage will also be
taken up and definite arrangements
for this important item will be
made. It is also proposed to complete promptly the main entrance
on Charles street.
The collections from the Endowment and Extension Fund are coming in rapidly, and large receipts
are expected by the first of the
year, so that by next spring the
University will be in a position to
undertake the active construction of
the needed buildings. It is hoped
that the commencement exercises
of 1915, the year of graduation of
the present freshman class, will be
held at Homewood.
"Freddie" Lee—Poet.

"One of the songs which attracted
. a great deal of attention at the St.
John's game on Saturday was by
"Freddie" Lee, who has blossomed
out into quite a poet. Any one who
reads the song can tell to what
music it can be sung. The words
follow :
We want a game,
Just like the game
We won a year ago.
It was a shame
How the money came
We put it on them so.
But today it's going to be much worse,
Old St. John's will surely need a hearse,
When we win this game
Just like the game
•
We won a year ago.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 20, 1911
A Woodrow Wilson Club.

The following letter has been received:

DEAR SIR:
You will see on November 15th,
either in the public press or in your
college publications, notices of the
movement inaugurated at the University of South Carolina, joined by
the University of Virginia, to establish a league of student clubs that
will work for the election of Woodrow Wilson as President of the
United States.
Your name has been furnished
us by authorities at your college as
that of a strong-minded Woodrow
Wilson man. We enclose herewith
the constitution of the league, and
submit to your consideration the
expediency of organizing in your
college a club of this league.
As the plan is to get all of these
organizations to work at the same
time as near as possible, and to have
them keep pace with the press, it is
advisable that you commence matters right away, the day the notices
appear. You will find it helpful to
yourself and to those you may associate under you, and a Woodrow
Wilson club in a college of the
standing of your institution will
mean much to a great cause. Do
not organize until November 15th,
as we want unity of effect.
You will hardly find it necessary
to have stated dues, or to have a
very strict organization, but your
membership should consist only of
earnest Wilson men.
We shall hope to hear from you
soon with a favorable report of the
progress of the work in your college.
With assurances of regard and
co-operation,
Very truly yours,

BROADIJS MITCHELL,
CorrespondingSecretary,TheWoodrow Wilson League of College
Men.

CONSTITUTION.
SLOGAN—We Want Wilson.
Alen= I. The name of this organization shall he: "The Woodrow Wilson
League of College Men."
ART. II. The object of this organization shall be to unite college • men
in promoting the candidacy of Woodrow Wilson for the presidency of the
United States.
ART. III. The officers of the league
shall consist of a president, a vice-president, a second vice-president, a corresponding secretary, a recording secretary, and a treasurer, whose duties
shall be such as commonly attach to
such offices in .organizations similar.
ART. IV. The league, in furtherance of its design, shall (I) conduct
correspondence, (2) solicit the support of the college press, (3) submit
articles for publication in the Democratic organs of the country, (4) interview delegates to the Democratic conventions, (5) seek and follow instructions from the Wilson Bureau; and (6)
by all these means endeavor to get
college men squarely behind the .college
man's candidate.

This letter and the proposed constitution, THE NEWS-LETTER prints
without comment. There are some
things to be said in favor of a club
at Hopkins, where Governor Wilson took his Ph.D., and there are
some arguments on the other side.
The question is: Do the faculty and
students want to form such a club?
To the Alumni.

You have probably noticed that
in the issues of THE NEWS-LETTER
which have reached you, more attention has been given to news of the
alumni than was the case last year.
Notes of this character are very
difficult to obtain, because in many
instances the graduates fail to inform the University authorities of
changes which they have made, and
because, other than the registrar's
office, there is no source of information accessible.
If alumni news is to be a regular feature of future issues, you
graduates, who are the ones most
concerned, will have to supply some
of the data. THE NEWS-LETTER is
always grateful to receive any items
about those who have studied or
taught at Johns Hopkins. Especially would we like to hear from
class secretaries and get from them
accounts of formal and informal
reunions. Every alumnus can furnish us with information about himself. A business card with a penciled note will suffice. Almost
every alumnus can furnish news
of his classmates who are not
reached by THE NEWS-LETTER.
Will you help us?

November 16, 1911.
To the Editor of THE

NMS-LETTER:

At the Virginia game a week ago,
there seemed to be but one thing lacking at Homewood: there was no
University flag or banner flying
from the pole where the national
flag was. It seems that a flag of
this description should be present
on days of important games when
it is thought necessary to raise the
American flag at the athletic field.
If the University were situated
now where it will be within two
years, perhaps there would be some
other place for a banner signifying
the University. But then it will be
less necessary, because the buildings
themselves will give Homewood a
Hopkins aspect. The University of
Pennsylvania has recently adopted
an official banner, and I have seen
the university flag flying from the
staff in front of the library at Columbia. The custom, it is seen, is ,
not without precedent and even if
it were, does it not seem urgent
to the Athletic Board to take steps
to have a Hopkins banner for
Homewood?
HOPKINS STUDENT.

'
11cCALLISTERS

D'ARTANYAN.

Why should enthusiastic students,
coaches, and alumni expend their
efforts at mass-meetings to rouse
the undergraduates to enthusiasm
for cheering; why urge them to
come to the games alone so that
they may sit in the cheering section
of the grandstand; why pay money
for bands and enlist the services of
cheer leaders, if the loyal undergraduate. is to find the so-called
cheering section filled when he
reaches the grounds by a large number of strangers who not only make
no pretense of rooting for Hopkins,
but, in some instances, show partiality for the opposing team?
I came to the Virginia game alone
some ten minutes before the time
for play to begin. At the massmeeting some days before I had
secured my ticket for a seat in the
cheering section—the fourth row,
near the band—where enthusiasm, I
felt sure, would be highest. The
usher, however, instructed me to go
"anywhere back of the band," and,
to my surprise, I found that not
only was there no seat for me in the
fourth row, but none anywhere
below the very top of the stand.
And when I came to look over the
crowd that had so unexpectedly
taken up the desirable positions in
I saw only too plainly
Section
that while there were a large number of Hopkins students present,
there were also a great many
strange faces, a number, those of
men, who I knew had no connection with the University. Instead of
cheering, many of my neighbors
were criticising the Hopkins players
and some professed more knowledge of the Virginia team than of
'ours. Possibly some were alumni,
but alumni who do not cheer do not
belong in the cheering section—at
least not in such numbers as to
separate the too-small number of
those who know and practice the
songs and yells.
If there .is to be a band, let the
singers be near enough to keep with
it; if there is to be a cheer leader,
let the rooters be close enough to
hear his instructions. The fifty or
seventy-five who come to the massmeetings and yell their lungs out at
the games deserve the best seats,
and should not have to yield place to
some hundreds who are never heard
except in carping criticism.

r,

STENTOR.

November 16, 1911.

THE NEWS
VOL. XVI, NO. 7.
FINNEY AS PRINCETON'S HEAD
The Unanimous Choice of Sub-Committee of Trustees --He Will
Probably Accept.

The sub-committee of the board
of trustees of Princeton University
appointed to select a nominee for
the presidency of the university, it
has been learned from trustworthy
sources, has come to a unanimous
agreement upon Dr. John M. T.
Finney, Associate Professor of
Surgery in the Johns Hopkins University, for the place. In the event
f unanimity in the sub-committee
it has all along been understood
that the trustees would accept the
recommendation. It is also understood that Dr. Finney will make no
decision in the matter until the
Opinion of the entire board has been
expressed. The next regular meeting of the trustees will be held in
January. Thus far no notice of a
special meeting has been given.
.The class of 1884, of which Dr.
Finney is a member, has forwarded
to him a letter of congratulation,
urging him to accept the presidency.
Members of the class think that he
will accept.
'His intimate connection with the
management of the Hopkins Medical School and its educational questions has been an important factor
in considering him for the presidency. Another factor commending him has been the fact that in
his work on the board of trustees
of Princeton since his election in
the spring of 1910 has been his
Special effort on the committee for
the reorganization of the department of physical education. He
was a member of the Baltimore
School Board for a time and is a
trustee of the Gilman School of
Baltimore.
In college they call Finney "J'ai
nni," because it sounded like his
name and because he finished
things. He was an athlete, playing
end on a football team that beat
both Havard and Yale. He did not
class with the first ten in scholarship but was a good student.
Dr. Finney is 48 years old, a
native of Harford county, Md. He
is the son of Rev. Ebenezer Finney, a Presbyterian minister. He
was educated in the Maryland
county schools, then Princeton, with
his medical education at Harvard.
At the meeting of the Philological Association, held last Friday,
the papers presented were as follows: "The Greek Aorist Passive
and the Germanic Weak Preterit,"
by Prof. Collitz ; "The Judaization
of Idumea," by Prof. Paul Haupt.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 20, 1911.

HOPKINS CRUSHES
ST. JOHN'S, 1610 0
A Crowd of Over 5,000 Witness
Battle on Sea of Mud.
THE SOLDIER BOYS OUTCLASSED
Rooters Out in Force With Bands to
Cheer the Squads—Game Ended
With Usual Snake Dance.

Once more the historic event of
the Hopkins football season resulted
in a triumph for the wearers of the
Black and Blue, when St. John's
went down to defeat last Saturday
by the decisive score of 16 to o.
Contrary to the predictions of the
wise dopesters and the warnings of
the knockers, Lynn's men "came
back" and proved that the regular
team of the present season is worthy
of the whole-hearted support of
their backers. Filled with a grim
determination to wipe out the defeat of the week before by winning the contest on which more than
anything else were staked the hopes
of the enthusiasts, the players went
into the game with a rush and snap
that overcame their opponents' wily
trick plays, broke up their runs,
tore through their lines, and eventually disheartened their whole organization.
A tremendous crowd assembled
for the contest. The rooters of
both sides were out in force with
their bands, and never left off
cheering their favorites during the
whole game. Although St. John's
had been the choice of the wise
ones during the whole week before,
it was seen that the wet condition
of the grounds, which would compel the employment of the old-time
straight football to a large extent,
was against their tactics, and the
local boys were correspondingly
more jubilant.
The first few minutes of play
seemed to exhaust the resources of
the soldier boys. Their forward
passes and clever tricks made a distinct impression during the first
quarter, but as the ball became wet
and the runners lost some of their
speed in the mud, the visitors were
seen to be unequal to the Hopkins
team. In particular, their backs
were unable often to get away from
the fast ends, who broke through
or around the line and frequently
threw the runners for a loss. On
the other hand, the Hopkins backs
showed speed when least expected,
and the interference protected them
admirably in running back kicks.

Stollenwerck's presence in the backfield was a distinct help to the men,
and the team was always a unit
with a single mind in control. Conditions were unfavorable for kicking, and the veteran quarter's efforts at field goals went wide time
after time. It was soon evident
that the game would be won largely
on line bucking, and here Hopkins
,excelled.
In open field work, the tackling
of Musser and "Johnnie" Morton
was often sensational. They broke
up many plays that threatened long
gains for the visitors. Bridgman,
as ever, was a consistent ground
gainer and showed his old knowledge of the fine points of the game.
He and Gillet would alternately
tAke the ball forward, and both
seemed utterly tireless in their
splendid plunging and running.
Fulton was relieved of much of the
overwork that had been his fate
when the team was stripped of the
older players, but during the time
he played he showed his usual brilliant form.
Rhode and Gittings won the
cheers of the grandstand by numerous brilliant plays. The former
especially showed head work constantly and helped the younger men
by his thorough knowledge of the
game. Pieper was always reliable
and worked hard throughout. The
backfield quartet was the best seen
in the Hopkins uniform this year,
and in spite of the slippery condition of the ball, it was handled almost without a mishap.
Bridgman kicked off to Melville,
who was downed on the 25-yard
line. The visitors immediately
worked a forward pass for a long
gain, but were compelled soon after
to kick. Bridgman and Gillet carried the ball rapidly down the field,
but St. Johns held on the 15-yard
line, secured the ball, and punted
out. A fumble lost the ball again,
but St. John's could not gain, and
Clayton kicked to Stollenwerck.
After some gains, Bridgman punted
back, and this time clever work and
good luck brought the visitors to
the Hopkins bo-yard line. Here St.
John's tried the forward pass that
had stood, them in such good stead
before. This time Claude fumbled,
and Hopkins secured the ball. After
sonic unsuccessful,tries through the
line, the bail was punted back again,
and at the close of the quarter was
in the possession of the visitors on
the 13-yard line.
When play was resumed, the
Black and Blue held for downs;
Bridgman and Stollenwerck made
brilliant gains. From this point St.
John's was always on the defensive.
Several kicks were exchanged arid

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TO BUILD IN THE SPRING
A Committee of Trustees, Faculty and
Alumni to Be Appointed to Supervise Work at Homewood.

Important announcements have
been made by President Remsen
in regard to the beginning of building operations at Homewood. A
committee of the trustees, faculty,
and alumni to take active charge
of the supervision of the work
is being made up and its personnel will be announced in a few
days. The committee will be modeled on the lines of the Endowment
and Extension Fund Committee of
1910, and will hold frequent meetings.
The preliminary plans are complete, and the work of finally deciding upon these, and awarding the
contracts, will be done this winter,
so that the construction can be
started in the spring, as soon as
the weather permits. Studies of
the Academic and Library Building-, the Administration, or Gilman,
Building, three laboratories and a
Y. M. C. A. building have been
made, and it will be the work of
the Committee to pass on these
plans, secure bids and make recommendations to the trustees for final
action. The question of steam-heat,
light and drainage will also be
taken up and definite arrangements
for this important item will be
made. It is also proposed to complete promptly the main entrance
on Charles street.
The collections from the Endowment and Extension Fund are coming in rapidly, and large receipts
are expected by the first of the
year, so that by next spring the
University will be in a position to
undertake the active construction of
the needed buildings. It is hoped
that the commencement exercises
of 1915, the year of graduation of
the present freshman class, will be
held at Homewood.
"Freddie" Lee—Poet.

"One of the songs which attracted
. a great deal of attention at the St.
John's game on Saturday was by
"Freddie" Lee, who has blossomed
out into quite a poet. Any one who
reads the song can tell to what
music it can be sung. The words
follow :
We want a game,
Just like the game
We won a year ago.
It was a shame
How the money came
We put it on them so.
But today it's going to be much worse,
Old St. John's will surely need a hearse,
When we win this game

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 20, 1911
A Woodrow Wilson Club.

The following letter has been received:

DEAR SIR:
You will see on November 15th,
either in the public press or in your
college publications, notices of the
movement inaugurated at the University of South Carolina, joined by
the University of Virginia, to establish a league of student clubs that
will work for the election of Woodrow Wilson as President of the
United States.
Your name has been furnished
us by authorities at your college as
that of a strong-minded Woodrow
Wilson man. We enclose herewith
the constitution of the league, and
submit to your consideration the
expediency of organizing in your
college a club of this league.
As the plan is to get all of these
organizations to work at the same
time as near as possible, and to have
them keep pace with the press, it is
advisable that you commence matters right away, the day the notices
appear. You will find it helpful to
yourself and to those you may associate under you, and a Woodrow
Wilson club in a college of the
standing of your institution will
mean much to a great cause. Do
not organize until November 15th,
as we want unity of effect.
You will hardly find it necessary
to have stated dues, or to have a
very strict organization, but your
membership should consist only of
earnest Wilson men.
We shall hope to hear from you
soon with a favorable report of the
progress of the work in your college.
With assurances of regard and
co-operation,
Very truly yours,

BROADIJS MITCHELL,
CorrespondingSecretary,TheWoodrow Wilson League of College
Men.

CONSTITUTION.
SLOGAN—We Want Wilson.
Alen= I. The name of this organization shall he: "The Woodrow Wilson
League of College Men."
ART. II. The object of this organization shall be to unite college • men
in promoting the candidacy of Woodrow Wilson for the presidency of the
United States.
ART. III. The officers of the league
shall consist of a president, a vice-president, a second vice-president, a corresponding secretary, a recording secretary, and a treasurer, whose duties
shall be such as commonly attach to
such offices in .organizations similar.
ART. IV. The league, in furtherance of its design, shall (I) conduct
correspondence, (2) solicit the support of the college press, (3) submit
articles for publication in the Democratic organs of the country, (4) interview delegates to the Democratic conventions, (5) seek and follow instructions from the Wilson Bureau; and (6)
by all these means endeavor to get
college men squarely behind the .college
man's candidate.

This letter and the proposed constitution, THE NEWS-LETTER prints
without comment. There are some
things to be said in favor of a club
at Hopkins, where Governor Wilson took his Ph.D., and there are
some arguments on the other side.
The question is: Do the faculty and
students want to form such a club?
To the Alumni.

You have probably noticed that
in the issues of THE NEWS-LETTER
which have reached you, more attention has been given to news of the
alumni than was the case last year.
Notes of this character are very
difficult to obtain, because in many
instances the graduates fail to inform the University authorities of
changes which they have made, and
because, other than the registrar's
office, there is no source of information accessible.
If alumni news is to be a regular feature of future issues, you
graduates, who are the ones most
concerned, will have to supply some
of the data. THE NEWS-LETTER is
always grateful to receive any items
about those who have studied or
taught at Johns Hopkins. Especially would we like to hear from
class secretaries and get from them
accounts of formal and informal
reunions. Every alumnus can furnish us with information about himself. A business card with a penciled note will suffice. Almost
every alumnus can furnish news
of his classmates who are not
reached by THE NEWS-LETTER.
Will you help us?

November 16, 1911.
To the Editor of THE

NMS-LETTER:

At the Virginia game a week ago,
there seemed to be but one thing lacking at Homewood: there was no
University flag or banner flying
from the pole where the national
flag was. It seems that a flag of
this description should be present
on days of important games when
it is thought necessary to raise the
American flag at the athletic field.
If the University were situated
now where it will be within two
years, perhaps there would be some
other place for a banner signifying
the University. But then it will be
less necessary, because the buildings
themselves will give Homewood a
Hopkins aspect. The University of
Pennsylvania has recently adopted
an official banner, and I have seen
the university flag flying from the
staff in front of the library at Columbia. The custom, it is seen, is ,
not without precedent and even if
it were, does it not seem urgent
to the Athletic Board to take steps
to have a Hopkins banner for
Homewood?
HOPKINS STUDENT.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

D'ARTANYAN.

Why should enthusiastic students,
coaches, and alumni expend their
efforts at mass-meetings to rouse
the undergraduates to enthusiasm
for cheering; why urge them to
come to the games alone so that
they may sit in the cheering section
of the grandstand; why pay money
for bands and enlist the services of
cheer leaders, if the loyal undergraduate. is to find the so-called
cheering section filled when he
reaches the grounds by a large number of strangers who not only make
no pretense of rooting for Hopkins,
but, in some instances, show partiality for the opposing team?
I came to the Virginia game alone
some ten minutes before the time
for play to begin. At the massmeeting some days before I had
secured my ticket for a seat in the
cheering section—the fourth row,
near the band—where enthusiasm, I
felt sure, would be highest. The
usher, however, instructed me to go
"anywhere back of the band," and,
to my surprise, I found that not
only was there no seat for me in the
fourth row, but none anywhere
below the very top of the stand.
And when I came to look over the
crowd that had so unexpectedly
taken up the desirable positions in
I saw only too plainly
Section
that while there were a large number of Hopkins students present,
there were also a great many
strange faces, a number, those of
men, who I knew had no connection with the University. Instead of
cheering, many of my neighbors
were criticising the Hopkins players
and some professed more knowledge of the Virginia team than of
'ours. Possibly some were alumni,
but alumni who do not cheer do not
belong in the cheering section—at
least not in such numbers as to
separate the too-small number of
those who know and practice the
songs and yells.
If there .is to be a band, let the
singers be near enough to keep with
it; if there is to be a cheer leader,
let the rooters be close enough to
hear his instructions. The fifty or
seventy-five who come to the massmeetings and yell their lungs out at
the games deserve the best seats,
and should not have to yield place to
some hundreds who are never heard
except in carping criticism.

The Ideal Room-Mate.

His suits are of the latest cut,
And fit you like your own;
His ties, his shirts, his suits, his socks,
Are your comparison.
His notes and lectures up to date,
His problems always done;
His check from home is never late,
Or credit over-run.
His only sister is a star,
He'll introduce you to her;
He lets you have his motor car,
His father is a brewer.
